resources.string: There is no location data saved. You can either download the data or manually enter the data.

Planet's Position v1.6

 Planets Position is a program to calculate the position of the planets in the night sky based on a given location on Earth.

 License and Copyright

 Copyright © 2012 Tim Gaddis

 This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or (at your option) any later version.

 This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. See the GNU General Public License for more details.

 You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License along with this program. If not, see 
 http://www.gnu.org/licenses/.

 Feedback can be sent to
 planets.position@gmail.com
 or @planetsposition on Twitter

 Source code available at GitHub.
 https://github.com/timgaddis/Planets-Position

 Swiss Ephemeris code is used in this program for planetary position calculations.
 http://www.astro.com/swisseph/swephinfo_e.htm?lang=e

 Change Log

 Version 1.6
 -Added North, South, East, West selections to the update location activity.
 -Added Eclipse Map activity that displays eclipse paths on Google Maps.
 -Added Internet permission for use with Google Maps.

 Version 1.5.4
 -Fixed force close at startup for devices with Android 2.X and below.
 -Added change log to about page.

 Version 1.5.3
 -Fixed forced close when leaving the Real Time Position activity.

 Version 1.5.2
 -Fixed force close when selecting next or prevoius in eclipse activities.
 -Fixed progress dialog not closing in User Location activity.

 Version 1.5.1
 -Fixed NumberFormatException in User Location activity when trying to save non-numbers.
 -Fixed NullPointerException in main activity when progress dialog is showing.
 -Fixed IllegalStateException when leaving User Location activity without saving a location.

 Version 1.5
 -Changed name of app to Planet's Position.
 -Updated the database and dialog code to be ICS compliant.
 -Redesigned UI to work better with tablets.
 -Renamed Planet's Position activity to Sky Position.
 -Moved user location to Update Location activity.

Initially, location data needs to be saved for the position calculations.
 The two options are to retrieve location data from GPS or manually enter all of the data. The location data is then saved to the program.

 The Sky Position screen lets you select a planet and a date and time, then it will calculate the position.

 The What's Up Now screen lists what planets are up for the current date and time of the device for the given location.

 The Solar Eclipse screen lists solar eclipses and indicates which of them are visible at the location saved on the device.

 The Lunar Eclipse screen lists lunar eclipses and indicates which of them are visible at the location saved on the device.

 The Real Time Position screen is the current real time position of the selected planet.

The Planet, Local Date, and Local Time fields are user changeable. Initially the Local Date and Local Time are set to the current date and time of the device.

 When a planet is selected, 8 values are calculated.

Right Ascension:
 The position on the celestial sphere east of the Vernal Equinox.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_ascension

Declination:
 The position on the celestial sphere north or south of the celestial equator.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declination

Azimuth:
 The compass direction for the planet's position for the given location.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azimuth

Altitude:
 The angle above the horizon of the given planet.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altitude_(astronomy)

Distance:
 The distance of the planet from the Earth in astronomical units.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_unit

Magnitude
 The brightness of a planet on a logarithmic scale, where the smaller the number, the brighter the planet.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnitude_(astronomy)

Rise and Set Times
 The times at which the planet rises and sets for the given location.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_rise
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunset

This is a list of the planets above the horizon at the current date and time.

 7 values are calculated for each planet.

Right Ascension:
 The position on the celestial sphere east of the Vernal Equinox.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_ascension

Declination:
 The position on the celestial sphere north or south of the celestial equator.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declination

Azimuth:
 The compass direction for the planet's position for the given location.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azimuth

Altitude:
 The angle above the horizon of the given planet.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altitude_(astronomy)

Distance:
 The distance of the planet from the Earth in astronomical units.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_unit

Magnitude
 The brightness of a planet on a logarithmic scale, where the smaller the number, the brighter the planet.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnitude_(astronomy)

Set Time
 The time at which the planet sets for the given location.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunset

When an eclipse is selected, 6 values are calculated.

 Eclipse Types:
 Total Eclipse
 Annular Eclipse
 Partial Eclipse
 Hybrid Eclipse
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_eclipse#Types

Azimuth:
 The compass direction for the Sun's position for the given location.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azimuth

Altitude:
 The angle above the horizon of the Sun.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altitude_(astronomy)

Magnitude:
 The brightness of the eclipse on a logarithmic scale, where the smaller the number, the brighter the eclipse.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnitude_(astronomy)

Saros Number:
Saros Member Number:
 The saros is a a period of 223 synodic months that can be used to predict eclipses of the Sun and Moon
 http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEsaros/SEsaros.html
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saros_number
 Eclipse Map is the path of totality for total, anular, or hybrid eclipses or maximum eclipse for partial eclipses.

When an eclipse is selected, 6 values are calculated.

 Eclipse Types:
 Total Eclipse
 Partial Eclipse
 Penumbral Eclipse
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lunar_eclipse#Types_of_lunar_eclipse

Azimuth:
 The compass direction for the Moon's position for the given location.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azimuth

Altitude:
 The angle above the horizon of the Moon.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altitude_(astronomy)

Magnitude:
 The brightness of the eclipse on a logarithmic scale, where the smaller the number, the brighter the eclipse.
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnitude_(astronomy)

Saros Number:
Saros Member Number:
 The saros is a a period of 223 synodic months that can be used to predict eclipses of the Sun and Moon
 http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEsaros/SEsaros.html
 http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saros_number
